title: Will Geert Wilders become prime minister of the Netherlands after the March 2017 elections?
preds: The resolution of this question is going to take a while. My guess is second half of June at the earliest.
No chance. There's no need for any of the parties to partner with him. And even if they did, they would certainly not make him Prime Minister.
Too bad for him he wasn't born in the US.  He'd be next in line behind Mr. Tangerine Man.

After the VVD's impressive showing in the recent elections, not only will Wilders be cut out of having any sort of plurality in the government, but likely will not be included in the governing coalition at all, and possibly from even an opposition coalition.

In the elections Wilders' PVV won only 20 seats, against 33 for Rutte's VVD. Furthermore VVD and CDA (the najor right wing parties) have tried before to cooperate with Wilders who proved to be an unpredictable partner. None of the left wing parties would ever be in a coaliton with Wilders. This leaves Wilders in an isolated position, without any chance of being prime minister.
He hasn't done and now won't do
Based on general news and GJP consensus.
Dropping from 1 to 0 due to election results.
After the election results this is completely zero probability. There would be new elections before I can a scenario that that emerge
One supposes this Q must be held open until either a government excluding him is actually formed or the Q closing date, whichever comes first.
Down to 0 now; he's not going to have any leverage given his poor showing.

I don't think it is possible anymore
https://www.theguardian.com/world/live/2017/mar/15/dutch-election-voters-go-to-the-polls-in-the-netherlands-live

First EXIT poll saying VVD 31 seats (from 150) followed by 3 parties with 19 namely D66, PVV and CDA.
Followed by GL:16, SP:14 and PvdA:9
At first sight: 2 possibilities for VVD to form a government without PVV (Wilders) 
1. VVD/D66/CDA/GL (4 parties)
2. VVD/D66/CDA/CU/SGP (5 parties)
Exit polls in the Netherlands (IPSOS) use to be very accurate.
Chance that Wilders becomes PM now is 0,00%

PVV could wind up with the most seats, but there is a very good chance that everyone will band together against it. Although it is possible wilders could make deals with one of the many fringe parties.
Turnout way higher than in the past could be caused to new "against-voters"

Wilders's Party Slumps in Final Dutch Polls on Election Eve
https://www.bloomberg.com/politics/articles/2017-03-14/wilders-party-slumps-in-shock-dutch-poll-on-eve-of-election

Latest polls show decreasing support for PVV going into election.  Decreasing by 10%.
https://home.noties.nl/peil/

With alle parties excluding him, he can only become prime minister when this party the PVV wins at least half the seats in parliament. I deem this impossible, the more so with declining polls for the PVV in recent weeks.

Down from 5% on 11 Jan. Seems even more unlikely, The most recent batch of opinion polls released in the last three days almost all show the PVV now in second place, whereas they had shown it in the lead for  the last five months, There had been a very small chance of his  becoming PM even if his party had topped the polls.
Even if he comes first in the polling he won't be able to locate enough playmates for form a government.

Wilders' party now trailing on 14.6 percent in Peilingwijzer's poll of polls behind Rutte's VVD on 16.4 percent, and the Christian Democrats not far behind on 12.1 percent,
http://www.reuters.com/article/us-netherlands-election-turkey-idUSKBN16F1CN?il=0

Dropping further because polls are now showing the PVV in second; and if somehow they come in first there aren't coalition partners out there. But Trump and Brexit happened so one percent for a hat trick.
Wilders is dropping in the polls, so this small probability decreases a bit further
Latest polls give him second place, which greatly reduces the probability in my view

PVV is in the lead by only 1 point, likely that will disappear by 15 Mar.
https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Opinion_polling_for_the_Dutch_general_election,_2017

VVD leads by 4 points, 28  to	24. No chance for Geert. Only 12 days to change these numbers.
https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Opinion_polling_for_the_Dutch_general_election,_2017
Passage of time and he's slipped in the polls.
Updating for change in opinion polls
Getting closer to the election and polls are not looking good.
Rutte Closes Gap With Populist Wilders in Dutch Election Poll

Nothing is impossible but the chances that he will are extremely small. Only if his one-member party PVV gets the majority of votes and 75 seats in parliament he will become prime minister as all the other major parties have indicated that they do not want to form a coalition with the PVV and definitely not when he would lead it as a prime minister. The only time his party cooperated in a government (as a support party) is still considered a drama during its short time of existence. Having said that, nobody knows what happens if a (major) terroristic attack hits the Netherland shortly before election.

The polls would have to be very wrong for Wilders' PVV to have such an overwhelming lead that the PVV would be able to form a government. In spite of the media talking up the "Brexit & Trump" turn to the populist right, the PVV is polling less than 20% support.

PVV is at 29%. It is still possible to form a governing coalition excluding his party. Highest probability since other parties don't want to leave the EU or Euro.
https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Opinion_polling_for_the_Dutch_general_election,_2017
if he can't form a coalition the question resolves as no as per 'n's comment 45174

Wilders is polling at < 20% well below the >50% threshold. Even the centre-right VVD has ruled out a coalition, so base case is a coalition government excluding the PVV or new elections (in which case question resolves as "no").
He is a long shot, but right wing populism is on the rise, especially in Europe. He may not win, but it will be much too close for comfort.

Wilders does not seem to be picking up any more support as the campaign continues. It could be that he has some shy supporters who are not being counted in the polls, but assuming that other parties are to be believed that they would not enter into coalition with him, he would need to pick up a lot more support to be appointed PM.

1) His party, the PVV is leading by far in two prediction markets.
PredictIt ( 77% ) https://www.predictit.org/home/browse?Search=dutch&isSearch=true
PaddyPower ( 77% as well ) http://www.paddypower.com/bet/politics/other-politics/european-politics?ev_oc_grp_ids=2904253
Very unlikely given his party would need coalition partners worth approx. 35% of seats in parliament, and many large parties are declining to work with the PVV.
impossible. rainbow coalition is always alternative.
Wilders doesn't seem to have coalition partners. And he'll need them. I'm not at zero because politicians are known to lie, in this case there could be some advantage to negotiating from a hard line.
The Dutch are pretty far back in the queue for the increasingly popular spine-removal surgery.  They are not scheduled until next year, I think.
Updating downward for passage of time. There's still only one party that would consider an alliance, so barring extreme events in the next month, I don't expect a change.
I suspect those who support Wilders will have a very high chance of reaching the polling station (relative to the other candidates).

With so many parties, and 70% of Dutch voters yet to make up their minds, predicting the election’s outcome is foolish. Easier to forecast is the direction of the country. 
Mr. Wilders was bullish in the interview about his ambitions for the coming election, telling The Telegraph: “I want to be prime minister. The question is if they want me to be prime minister… The odds of me becoming prime minister, are perhaps not in my favour, but I’m confident that if we get the result, according to the current polls that it is a real possibility.” 
But Mr. Wilders admitted it was possible other parties could refuse to cooperate with him, opening the way for a minority coalition to rule although he could command the largest single party. A similar fate could await his colleagues in other European nations, he said, but even if Marine Le Pen in France and Sebastian Kurz in Austria failed to top the ballots in 2017 the populist revolution would carry on going. 
http://www.breitbart.com/london/2017/02/11/wilders-whatever-happens-2017-populist-genie-bottle/

COMMENT: Because of the upsets of Brexit and Trump with the polls, it is becoming so difficult now to make a forecast on these, and considering the times we are living it becomes even more difficult.
Two interviews heard this week have made me think again. One with Rutte and one with Wilders.
Polls show him leading by wide margins and Nationalist candidates usually outperform polls because of deirability bias.

The other parties are still holding firm in refusing to play with him no matter where he finishes in the election.  However, spine removal surgery has become very common among Western politicians of late, so coming up a couple.
Due to the fragmentation of the Dutch system, even if the PVV finishes first, a coalitio  without it will be formed, with mr Rutte most likely again as prime minister.

Though the polls have him leading. It is possible they have over estimated following their poor performance in 2016.  There is also the caveat to the question. Which is more important. If he does win his margin will not be great enough to form a government following the result.
It's likely that he will win the election, but looks unlikely that he will become the prime minister

It is possible to form government minus the PVV, and all other parties are united against him and his desire to drag them out of the EU.
https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Opinion_polling_for_the_Dutch_general_election,_2017
They're polling well but from what I've read it's unlikely they'll get a majority outright nor be able to form a coalition.

That Wilders become PM the PVV must lead a coalition. The last politieke barometer as a prediction was at 19.1.2017 (http://www.ipsos-nederland.nl/ipsos-politieke-barometer/barometer-van-deze-week). So I start with this numbers: currently there is no coalition between three parties possible, because they need 76 seats in the "Tweede Kammer" and the best coalition would only get 72 (VVD, PVV, CDA or VVD, PVV, D66).
Then there are 19 possible coalition between 4 parties. All of them need participation of VVD and PVV. Currently they would both get 27 seats so even if they come together Wilders would not become PM. Beside this the current PM Rutte said that the chance of a coworking between PVV and VVD would be 0% (http://nos.nl/artikel/2153087-rutte-kans-op-regering-vvd-met-pvv-is-nul.html). 
There are also 24 coalitions between five parties possible. 14 of them would be also lead by VVD but that mean there are also 10 under lead of PVV. 4 of this are together with PvdA and they do not want to work together with PVV (http://nos.nl/artikel/2152980-pvda-voorzitter-spekman-henk-en-mark-zeg-nee-tegen-de-pvv.html). Remain 6 under lead of PVV but they also all need CDA as a partner and they made bad experience with PVV in cabinet Rutte one from 2010 till 2012. And also one of the politicians from CDA said, that he would will go, if they work together (http://www.omroepbrabant.nl/?news/2548851263/CDAer+Ren%C3%A9+Peters+uit+Oss+samenwerken+met+PVV+uitgesloten.aspx). But I did not found a clear statement against it, so maybe it is possible. I think coalitions with 6 parties are not able to work together.
So I get 5 of 43 coalitions that would be lead by PM Wilders mean 11,6% possibility. From there on I would correct at may to 13% because there is also the possibility  that 6 parties work together. And then I get my numbers out of a prediction and there are still two months to go to the election, so maybe PVV is getting more seats than VVD what would change my model again. So I correct the 13% to 18% because of this.
If you have any suggestions or something that other politicians said, please reply.
And the website with the coalition where you also can deal with predictions that happen later: http://www.coalitiemeter.nl/

Small chance Wilders will find coalition partner to form a government. 
Likely it will take time to form an unstable coalition but Mr. Wilders party will be excluded from that coalition.

The Freedom party will most likely have the most seats in parliament with anywhere between a fifth and a quarter of the seats and could get as much as 30% of the vote but the other parties will definitely prevent them from forming a minority government by creating a their own coalition with a majority of the other parties.
The cordon sanitaire on the PVV will hold. He won't get to be the PM.
He will be unable to ally with others to form government even if he finishes first.

He will most probably win the election, but it looks like none of the other parties will form a coalition with him. Then, even if they do, a condition will most probably be that he doesn't become PM. The final nail in the coffin for me is that it seems to take a long time in the Netherlands to form a government (average 72 days since WWII), and this question expires 1 May 2017, so, given all these factors, I think the chance is zero.
Presumably this means "as a result of" the March elections, and not in 2036 after some other elections, which would of course also be "after" the March '17 ones.
Been wrong about this stuff before. Reducing certainty.
General election: Latest poll of polls shows slight drop in PVV support

The rhetoric around the lack of coalition support for Wilders makes this a low probability, but given the rise in populism, I am skewing up from 0 on the off-chance of support from the rising tide tipping more parties to negotiate with him if he picks up his lead in the polls

Dutch elections are one thing, and the complex and time consuming aftermath of government forming is another.  The polls have Wilders' PVV getting a plurality, but not enough to form a gov on his own. Now the 'brass tacks' of this question: Who would join a PVV lead coalition?

Comparing how PVV was polling a year ago it has been slowly loosing ground (were polling up to 42 seats, now polling 33 seats). It is the leading party, but to be PM Wilders not only needs to be leader of the leading party, but to be able to form a government.  76 seats would seem to be needed to have a government with a majority so the PVV would need to be part of a multi-party coalition. As the PVV is regarded by many (maybe most) Dutch voters as toxic it would probably struggle to form a majority coalition.  The VVD (the party of the current PM and close to the PVV in the polls) has ruled out joining with the PVV in a coalition. The VVD would probably find it a lot easier to build a coalition without the PVV. Although it is usual for the leader of the party with the most seats to become PM, this assumed that this party will be able to form a government. Events in the next eight weeks could change things, but its unlikely to change that much.
http://www.forbes.com/sites/marcelmichelson/2017/01/16/dutch-elections-could-turn-into-cliff-hanger-over-populist-party-eu-attitude-at-risk/#1ef768ec1b5d

On one side: Would consider the probability lower since Trump's election and the statement he made there is an even higher urge for Europe to stand up and unify.
On the other side: populists are on the rise and some people might feel confirmed by the words Trump chose about his own country first
Only if there is a major adverse political event that aligns with his platform.
I give him the same odds Trump had. Populism is on the rise and doesn't seem to be going away.

Not really my area of expertise, I expect PVV to win enough seats to make this plausible and I think the atmosphere in Europe right now is not good for mainstream parties to defy the will of the people.
Blindly following a median of people I follow.

Opinion polls (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Opinion_polling_for_the_Dutch_general_election%2C_2017) show Wilders' party PVV losing influence and the current PM Rutte's party (VVD) gaining seats. Also see @Rene's comments (https://www.gjopen.com/comments/comments/424005). I am going out on a limb here also betting that Trump's recent statements about Europe have scared voters in the Netherlands. So no, won't happen.

Polls for recent western political events have underestimated the polarising wave of populism manifest in some form in developed economies. I maintain that this is still unlikely (i.e. <50%), but polling could be skewed for a number of reasons such as over-sampling or simply due to those unwilling to publicly express views others regard as unsavoury when surveyed. A coalition is plausible.
Dutch prime minister Mark Rutte has ruled out participating in a government with far-right leader Geert Wilders, making it less likely that Wilders becomes prime minister after elections on 15 March.
No, and the person who wins won't have expected to win.

Staying at 1%
Rationale:
'Peilingwijzer' is a joint poll from 4 other polls (Politieke Barometer, De Stemming, I&Oresearch, Kantar TNS) 
According to 'Peilingwijzer' the biggest 5 are now:
- PVV (Geert Wilders)  between 29 and 33 seats (from 150). Or between 19% and 22%
- VVD between 23 and 27 seats
- CDA between 15 and 17 seats
- D66 between 14 and 17 seats
- GL between 13 and 15 seats
Extreme difficult coalition-forming process because VVD/CDA/D66/GL together hardly make 76 form 150 seats. And no parties wants to work with PVV's Geert Wilders.

Concurring parties have announced to be unwilling to co-operate with PVV after the elections in March. I believe this is an incentive for voters pro PVV to decide to vote (as opposed to not vote at all) which will result in a greater gain voor PVV in the elections, and therefore a stronger position for Wilders to request the position of prime minister, 18-01-2017.

Even if Wilders wins and the others are willing to negotiate, it has taken on average 72 days for the government to be formed in the past. There are 47 days between March 15 and May 1st, and the negotiations will not be easy given that no-one wants to work with Wilders. https://www.bloomberg.com/politics/articles/2017-01-18/your-guide-to-dutch-elections-a-bellwether-to-european-populism

The Emperor has no clothes. The European Union unelected elite is grossly out of touch with the European people, the reality on the ground in the Netherlands and across Europe.  Geert Wilders will be the next Prime Minister of the Netherlands. While Trump is a positive thing in Geert's favor, it will not be the reason for his victory. People understand that the EU has already failed and on artificial life support. There is no realistic path towards the European political union that is needed to save the Euro and the EU. The Islamization of parts of the Netherlands is a real concern to many Dutch and they will make their voices heard on election day.
It's really unlikely that Geert Wilders would became PM of Netherlands. Even winning he has no support from any other political party that could give him the necessary seats to become PM.

I start at zero because no major party in the Netherlands is willing to enter a coalition with Wilders party and so he should be mathematically eliminated. However, this is the age of uncertainty, Brexit, and Trump so I will add a point for each of those. Not very scientific I don't want to eliminate the possibility that Wilders continues to rise in the polls and manages to win enough seats that he can convince smaller parties to join him in a coalition.

Geert Wilders would need to get a coalition of 76 seats. Even if one suspects him to increase his 12 seats from 2012, he would need to be the major partner of the coalition to become prime minister. Combining his chances of winning an overall majority on his own (which I would put at most at 0.5%, as he would need to increase his seat share by a magnitude of 6) with his chances of becoming partner in a majority coalition, which I would still only put at 2% because all parties refuse to make a coalition with the VVD. The most suitable partner - VVD - has declared it won't make a coalition with Wilders and is losing many seats compared to 2012. He stands at best a chance of just over 2% of forming a government - alone or in a two-way coalition. As all parties refuse to govern with him and the Dutch electoral system represents many smaller parties, the odds of him forming a coalition with more than one party are smaller the more parties would need to be involved. Thus I would reduce it to 1.5%. But the fact that if he were to get a coalition organised, the PVV would most likely be the major partner and therefore win the position of prime minister. That makes me raise it to 2% again. It is also interesting that the PVV's performance has not improved since the Berlin attack, which makes me doubt whether a renewed terrorist attack would help raise the PVV's seat share considerably. In any case, it would need to be a big shift to overcome the odds and gain an absolute majority. If anything, previous elections have shown that his party tends to underperform on election day compared to opinion polls, which further reduces his odds - down to 1%.

The party of WIlders will probably end first, and some of the parties want to govern with him, but all in all this will probably not lead to a majority (so no WIlders as prime minister). The most logical coalition is PVV/VVD (although the leader said no, but hey, its politics)/50Plus (total is 67, and there at 76 seets needed).
Cuz of all the links about other parties refusing to be in a coalition with his party
29 seats would not be a strong enough showing to form a government.
10 viable parties. has a strong right - wing and anti immigration stance which is a popular movement. likely to go higher if further terror incidences occur between now and march 2017.

Probability is Wilders will gain the most seats and votes however the coalition will be stacked against him.  He will need to overperform in the actual election vs the polls to narrow the gap against the coalition and then try and get either additional support or abstainees.
netherland-survey says he is leading - but they can not be trusted,last election it was big fail
The comments from the VVP saying that there is 0 chance that they will form a coalition is pretty strong. Makes this event quite unlikely.
Nobody wants this, which these days substantially increases the odds that it will happen.  Moving up a little bit.
Currently leads polls, but opposition leaders publicly reluctant to form coalition with him.
Past polls on wikipedia seemed accurate and a coalition seems near impossible.
In my opinion he will. It goes along with the Brexit and the election of Donald Trump.

In the past decades the Netherlands were located on the more liberal side of European politics. Does this tradition necessarily contradict the rise of an intolerant party? It could also make a more outspoken approach in long standing interethnic conflicts (some dating back to colonial times) more likely and thereby gives rise to a rightwing populist government.

PvdA, SP, GL already said they will not govern with PVV.
PM Rutte (VVD) today siad that the chance  VVD will govern with PVV "is zero percent; it will not happen". 
And D'66 and CDA don't believe they will work together with PVV.
So the chance is less then 1 % , but I would like to express that the chance is not zero in case of a terrorist attack in the Netherlands before election day.
Major Parties have constantly said that they will not cooperate with him.

collaboration between PVV and other political parties will be necessary.

other candidates are not a serious challange for Rutte, Asher and Wilders
...
Wilders' PVV may become the biggest party after the elections, but he has very little potential allies. His party organization is very minimal and leader centric.

I am in the finance industry and follow this issue loosely
According to Mark Rutte, current prime-minister and leader of the VVD, the chances that the VVD wil form a coalition with the PVV are "not 0.1, but zero (...) It won't happen".

Despite the PVVâ€™s strong position in the polls, Wilders is extremely unlikely to become prime minister because of the Dutch system of coalition politics. Although the leader of the biggest party after the election is invited to form a government, all the other major parties have said they will not work with the PVV.
http://www.dutchnews.nl/news/archives/2016/12/geert-wilders-pvv-stretches-lead-in-latest-poll-of-polls/

Two base rates needed: probability that PVV is biggest party, and probability that Wilders can get a coalition running. Article linked by @DBrownian suggests 20-25% support for PVV, 15-18% for VVD. Even with all uncertainties, would suggest p>60%  that PVV wins, but not in such a landslide that other parties would feel forced to cooperate (at most 10%). Joint probability is 0.60*0.1 = 6%

As mentioned by @Nik (https://www.gjopen.com/comments/comments/423189)  there is no fixed enddate on this question. I still think it's very unlikely that Wilders will become prime-minister, but there's is a small chance of a coalition between VVD, PVV and 50+

An article I read in the Irish Times indicates that while his party may be poised to win the most seats in Parliament, it is "highly unlikely" that he can form a government with other parties, as they have stated that they will not work with him.
His brand of populism is on the way out.

likelihood that the PVV becomes the biggest party is about 55% (VVD is contester). The largest party gets the first shot at forming a government which might be difficult for the PVV. So my base case is that the PVV will be excluded from governing like it has been in the past few cabinets

Other parties have said outright they will not form a coalition government with PVV. If he wins in a landslide maybe the lure of government will tempt some other party to consider. http://www.dutchnews.nl/news/archives/2016/12/geert-wilders-pvv-stretches-lead-in-latest-poll-of-polls/
Wilders'party PVV does very well in predictions, but to become Prime Minister he needs support of at least two other parties. Given his terrible reputation this isn't going to happen.

Far-right leader unlikely to become PM as other parties say they won’t work with him
A new poll of polls in the Netherlands indicates that far-right leader Geert Wilders has consolidated his popularity since his conviction a fortnight ago for incitement to discrimination – and that his Freedom Party would be the largest party in the Dutch parliament if an election were held tomorrow.
The end-of-year poll, an amalgamation of data from five of the country’s leading pollsters, shows that Mr Wilders would win 31-37 seats in the 150-seat parliament. This would give his anti-immigrant, anti-Islam, anti-EU party the support of 20-25 percent of the electorate.
http://www.irishtimes.com/news/world/europe/geert-wilders-extends-lead-in-polls-ahead-of-dutch-election-1.2914769
Dutch Freedom Party leader Geert Wilders  tweeted a provocative photo of Angela Merkel with blood on her hands as he blamed Europe's 'cowardly leaders' for a 'tsunami' of Islamic terrorist attacks. 
In a previous tweet, he wrote: 'They hate and kill us. And nobody protects us. Our leaders betray us. We need a political revolution. And defend our people. #BerlinAttack.'
Because I dont believe the polls. Nothing is impossible, but it sure seems unlikely.

External rational:
Untill date 81 political parties registered for the national elections of March 15. 
The Netherlands have a history of multi-party cabinets. The average time it took with the last 26 national elections (since 1945) was 72 days (in a wide range).  The IPSOS-results forcast like 29 seats (from 150).  
Internal perspective:
Even when PVV (Geert Wilders 'personal' political party) would take 40 seats he would have the first right to try to form a government. But there would not be a chance that he could form whatever kind of cabinet, because nobody in the Parliament trusts him and (almost) nobody wants to work together with him. There is not an official agreement of a 'cordon sanitair' but practically there is. Realistically spoken he only could form a government if he would win more then 75 seats and be a potentate. Or he would have to be the party with the highest number of seats and have the initative to form a cabinet.  Winning > 75 seats < 1 % even if I correct for my 'just-world-bias' . This scenario only could happen in case of an not-so black swan (serious terrorist attack) in the Netherlands before the election day from IS or another group that could be linked to 'Muslims'.  
But 'only' becoming the biggest party in the House of Parliament - with 40-60 seats - I would say a small (but not neglect-able) change of between 3 or 5%. The closing day of this question puzzles me and might be most important part of just prediction and our Briere-scores.
The desire to exclude Dhr Wilders and his party is very strong, and he would require close to a majority to stop a coalition from forming to appoint the PM.
He would have to win in a landslide giving his party absolute majority. Otherwise they'll built a coalition against him.
Reversing per @Rene: http://www.gjopen.com/comments/comments/420987 but leaving a bit more room for uncertainty.

Most likely is a broad coalition of 4-5 political parties. Most parties have already made clear that they will not join a coalition with the PVV. Now, these are politicians, so you can't be sure, but I think it is very unlikely.

https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Opinion_polling_for_the_Dutch_general_election,_2017
Unlike in France, simple plurality in a single round wins the highest office. Unless I am missing something. @Rene - am I?
With the rise of Populism across the developed world, the liklihood of Wilders becoming Prime Minister is still unlikely, however, the same was said of Donald Trump, Brexit and the rise of UKIP.
I think centrist coalition will form a government and PVV will be sidelined. On the other hand polls show that PVV with Mr. Wlders will take second or maybe even first place in upcomng elections.
Will win the popular vote but most likely not find a coalition partner

PVV is leading the polls and is in a rising trend. Mr Wilders GAINED in popularity after being convicted for his relatively harmless statements about Moroccans which clearly indicates the anti-immigration sentiment in the Netherlands and his popularity. This is just another part of the global anti-globalist trend. The establishment will fight with tooth and nail but they will eventually acknowledge the will of the people.

While leading the polls, his party is unlikely to be able to govern alone, and given certain contentious positions (such as that against the UE and Islam) he is unlikely to be able to form a coalition that would accept him as premier. Maybe his party could become part of a governing coalition.

It will compete in a Netherlands who sees the uncertainty of Brexit and the Election of Trump. Especially the fact that both created the issues - inequality, less jobs etc. that they were declaring to want to prevent.
